title: Ladder Problem Explorer
description: Interactive visualization of the classic related rates ladder problem, showing how the rate of change of the ladder's height depends on base position and sliding speed. Students can see why the top speeds up as it approaches the ground.
creator: Dan McCreary
subject: Calculus
Related Rates
Derivatives
Implicit Differentiation
learningObjectives: Calculate the rate of change of the ladder's height given different positions and sliding speeds of the base
Apply implicit differentiation to derive the related rates equation
Explain why the top of the ladder speeds up as it approaches the ground

controls.name: lengthSlider
controls.label: Ladder Length L
controls.description: Total length of the ladder in feet

controls.name: speedSlider
controls.label: Base Speed db/dt
controls.description: Rate at which the base slides away from the wall in ft/sec

controls.name: positionSlider
controls.label: Base Position b
controls.description: Manual control of base distance from wall in feet

controls.name: playPauseButton
controls.label: Play/Pause
controls.description: Start or stop the ladder animation

variables: b - horizontal distance from wall to base
h - vertical height of ladder top
db/dt - rate of change of base position
dh/dt - rate of change of height
assumptions: Ladder remains in contact with both wall and ground
Wall and ground meet at a right angle
Ladder is rigid with fixed length
Base slides at constant rate (db/dt is constant)
limitations: Does not account for friction or real-world ladder dynamics
Infinite speed predicted as h approaches 0 is physically unrealistic
Assumes perfect sliding contact at both ends
